{{Han etym}}
{{liushu|p}} ‚Äì originally two pieces of jade crossed over each other as used in ancient shamanistic practices.

subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
; ‚Äúshaman; witch‚Äù
: This word initially referred to spirit medium/shaman of either sex, but eventually female when contrasted with {{och-l|Ë¶°|male shaman}}. Various hypotheses exist regarding its etymology ({{zh-ref|Schuessler, 2007}}):

:# Cognate with {{och-l|Ë™£|to deceive}}.

:# Cognate with {{och-l|ÊØç|female}}.
:# {{w|Victor Mair}} (1990) and {{w|Jao Tsung-I}} (1990) proposed that this is a loanword from {{cog|peo|êé∂êé¶êé¢êèÅ|tr=magu≈°}} (more at [[:w:Magi#Possible_loan_into_Chinese|Wikipedia: Magus]]). ({{zh-ref|Mair, 1990}}; {{zh-ref|Mair, 2012}}).

: {{cog|th|‡∏´‡∏°‡∏≠||doctor}} < {{cog|tai-pro|* ∞mo:·¥¨||shaman}} is generally assumed to be a Sino-Tibetan loan ({{zh-ref|Pittayaporn, 2014}}). More at {{w|Wu (shaman)}}, {{w|Magi#In Chinese sources}}, {{m|en|magus}}.

; ‚ÄúMalay‚Äù
